Westside Future Fund is proud to announce another milestone in its mission to support community stability and empowerment in Atlanta’s historic Westside.

Elisha Dumas recently became the owner of a three-bedroom, two-bathroom home along the James P. Brawley corridor in the English Avenue neighborhood through WFF’s signature affordable housing initiative, Home on the Westside.

Dumas’s role as an employee at Mercedes-Benz Stadium perfectly aligns with WFF’s community retention guidelines, which prioritize housing for individuals with live, work and learn connections to the historic Westside. Dumas received a combined $110,000 in down payment and financial assistance from WFF, Invest Atlanta and Atlanta Housing — turning his dream of homeownership into reality.

Congratulations, Elisha!

It's the beginning of new opportunities, renewed hope, and lasting change in the lives of so many individuals in our communities. Tamarose's mission is to provide safe, affordable, and service-oriented housing. We are extremely excited to be chosen by St. Joseph's Mercy Care to be their partner in this awesome development. Our mission is about facilitating transformative healing. When the Sisters of Mercy came to Atlanta, they built Atlanta's first hospital, St. Joseph's in primary. They asked what do the poor and vulnerable citizens of this community need. In their decision was not just a desire to live out their faith and beliefs, but also the courage to do what had not been done before. To push the envelope and to drive innovation to those who are usually the last to benefit from it. I remember when we did the groundbreaking and I saw it as it was under construction, and I got excited. It's great to be standing on top of this rooftop to look at the views that residents will have. This project represents a significant step towards addressing the national affordable housing crisis. The residents of Macauley station will have access to Mercy Care medical services because in my determination, housing is health care. And let's not forget, let's born and come. So this is phase one, this is a beautiful all ready. So thank you, thank you, thank you for delivering all your promise. This is near and near the Mont Arct because my entire being, if you will, literally in shadows where we stand right now. My schooling, my church, my hospital, all of it, within probably one mile radius of year. What a whole circle moment for me to come back to a half years later and see this building and see this community that has risen from this gravel lot. We're proud to partner with everyone here at Provide Homes and a community for 170 families. Next in the last year, we have committed over $300 million to affordable housing here at Mont Arct. We're only here on this place for a very small period of time. This is the bottom legacy that we're going to live behind to say, at the end of the day, I feel all I can to make a difference. Affordable housing, as we know, is very critical and in an investor plan, we really see housing as a spectrum of need from homeless to home ownership, do everything in between to ensure that whatever you want to choose as a place or how you want to live, you can find that option here in the city of Atlanta. This development, it stands as a testament to the dedication, the commitment, and the hard work of all of our partners. Together we're building strong communities and brighter futures, so thank you all for being here to celebrate this milestone. Last week, we celebrated our Get Procured cohorts in Atlanta and Jackson, MS. For the last several months, these business owners have gone through extensive training to learn  the local, state, and federal procurement processes and have been connected to industry leaders for real-time workshops and training.

Currently, only 1.6% of federal contracts go to Black-owned businesses. We’re focused on improving that number. Last week, we celebrated businesses that were awarded the first contracts, those who’ve won their largest contracts to date, and everything in between. 

We do this work with wellness serving as the anchor. As we focus on scaling businesses, we know you cannot neglect to scale your mindset and create a nurturing environment for yourself.

I couldn’t be more proud of my team at @ourvillageunited and our partners at the City of Atlanta, APS, Invest Atlanta, SBA, and many more!

Many congratulations to our pitch winners and every Villager. 

Thank you @shedoeverything for being our guest speaker in both cities. You are incredible, and I am thankful for your sisterhood.

The Invest Atlanta Board of Directors provided final approval of bond financing to create or preserve 391 affordable housing units at its September meeting, according to Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens. The approved financing will help develop affordable housing at a range of area median incomes (AMI), including low-income residents at 30% of the AMI to help close the housing affordability gap in the city. 

Developments that received final approval include: Cosby Spear Highrise.
A $49.5 million tax exempt loan is helping support the preservation of 282 senior housing units in the Old Fourth Ward neighborhood, according to a release. 

Also Sweet Auburn Grande, a $28.3 million tax-exempt loan will preserve 109 multifamily housing units in the Sweet Auburn neighborhood, according to a release. This is a history building in the Sweet Auburn Historic District that was originally built in 1908.

Actor and filmmaker #TylerPerry is donating $2.75 million to older homeowners in #Atlanta to help ensure they’re able to stay in their homes.

A few weeks ago, Perry reached out to Atlanta Mayor Andrew Dickens about providing assistance for those residents on fixed incomes who could lose their homes as a result of rising real estate taxes, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported.

Perry, ranked third among the world’s highest-paid entertainers by Forbes, is going to pay the back property taxes for 300 low-income seniors in Atlanta, the newspaper said.

The assistance will cover city, county and school taxes. Perry will also cover any increase in taxes over the next 20 years for 100 low-income older residents. He has already donated $750,000 for the first year to cover the back taxes and any increase in property taxes, and has pledged $500,000 each year over the next four years to ensure the residents don’t pay any more in such taxes.
